text.headline: Eusthenopteron
text.text: A fleshy-finned fish from the Late Devonian of North America. Its fossils were found in the Escuminac Formation in Quebec, Canada.It was a fleshy-finned fish, 3 ft (1 m) long.

text.headline: Cyclurus
text.text: A primitive ray-finned fish from the Early Cretaceous to the present. Its fossils were found in the Morrison Formation of Wyoming. It was a primitive ray-finned fish, 2 ft (0.6 m) long.

text.headline: Platysomus
text.text: A deep-bodied fish from the Early Carboniferous of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Bear Gulch Limestone in Scotland. It was a deep-bodied fish, 1 ft (0.3 m) long.

text.headline: Saurichthys
text.text: A primitive ray-finned fish from the Early Triassic of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Triassic deposits of Germany. It was a primitive ray-finned fish, 3 ft (1 m) long.

text.headline: Cheirolepis
text.text: A primitive ray-finned fish from the Middle Devonian of Europe. It was discovered in the Old Red Sandstone in Scotland. It was a primitive ray-finned fish, 1 ft (0.3 m) long.

text.headline: Leptolepis
text.text: A primitive ray-finned fish from the Late Jurassic of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Solnhofen Limestone in Germany. It was a primitive ray-finned fish, 1 ft (0.3 m) long, that looked like a herring.

text.headline: Pteronisculus
text.text: A small ray-finned fish from the Early Triassic of Europe. Its fossils were discovered in the Triassic deposits of Germany. It was a small ray-finned fish, 6 inches (15 cm) long.

text.headline: Ceratodus
text.text: A lungfish from the Late Devonian of Africa and Australia. Its fossils were found in the Elliot Formation of South Africa. It was a lungfish, 6 ft (1.8 m) long, with large, rounded teeth.

text.headline: Arandaspis
text.text: A primitive jawless fish from the Early Ordovician of Australia. Its fossils were found in the Stairway Sandstone. It was a primitive jawless fish, 8 inches (20 cm) long.

text.headline: Jamoytius
text.text: A jawless fish from the Late Silurian of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Lesmahagow Inlier in Scotland. It was a jawless fish, 8 inches (20 cm) long, with an eel-like body.

text.headline: Pteraspis
text.text: A jawless fish from the Early Devonian of Europe. Its fossils were discovered in the Downton Castle Sandstone in England. It was a jawless fish, 1 ft (0.3 m) long, with a pointed snout.

text.headline: Cephalaspis
text.text: A jawless fish from the Early Devonian of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Downton Castle Sandstone in England. It was a jawless fish, 1 ft (0.3 m) long, with a bony head shield.

text.headline: Osteolepis
text.text: A fleshy-finned fish from the Middle Devonian of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Old Red Sandstone in Scotland. It was a fleshy-finned fish, 1 ft (0.3 m) long.

text.headline: Dipterus
text.text: A lungfish from the Middle Devonian of Europe. It was discovered in the Old Red Sandstone in Scotland. It was a lungfish, 1 ft (0.3 m) long, that could breathe air.

text.headline: Latimeria
text.text: A living fossil from the Late Devonian to the present day. It was discovered off the coast of South Africa. It is a living fossil, 6 ft (1.8 m) long, that was thought to be extinct.

text.headline: Cladoselache
text.text: A primitive shark from the Late Devonian of North America. Its fossils were found in the Cleveland Shale in Ohio. It was a primitive shark, 3 ft (1 m) long.

text.headline: Stethacanthus
text.text: A primitive shark from the Early Carboniferous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Bear Gulch Limestone in Montana. It was a primitive shark, 2 ft (0.6 m) long, with a unique spine and bristle-covered patch on its back.

text.headline: Helicoprion
text.text: A primitive shark from the Early Permian of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Phosphoria Formation in Wyoming. It was a primitive shark, 23 ft (7 m) long, with a whorl of teeth.

text.headline: Xenacanthus
text.text: A primitive shark from the Early Permian of North America and Europe. Its fossils were found in the Clear Fork Group in Texas. It was a primitive shark, 3 ft (1 m) long, with a sharp spine behind its head.

text.headline: Hybodus
text.text: A primitive shark from the Early Cretaceous of Europe. It was discovered in the Wealden Group of Sussex, England. It was a primitive shark, 6 ft (1.8 m) long, with two dorsal fins.

text.headline: Climatius
text.text: A spiny shark from the Late Silurian of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Lesmahagow Inlier in Scotland. It was a spiny shark, 6 inches (15 cm) long, with large eyes.

text.headline: Ischnacanthus
text.text: A spiny shark from the Early Devonian of Europe. It was discovered in the Downton Castle Sandstone in England. It was a spiny shark, 6 inches (15 cm) long, with rows of spines.

text.headline: Dunkleosteus
text.text: A placoderm from the Late Devonian of North America. Its fossils were found in the Cleveland Shale in Ohio. It was a placoderm, 33 ft (10 m) long, with massive bony plates on its head.

text.headline: Gemuendina
text.text: A placoderm from the Early Devonian of Europe. It was discovered in the Hunsrück Slates in Germany. It was a placoderm, 1 ft (0.3 m) long, with an armored head.

text.headline: Dinichthys
text.text: A placoderm from the Late Devonian of North America. Its fossils were found in the Cleveland Shale in Ohio. It was a placoderm, 11 ft (3.5 m) long, with a bony jaw.

text.headline: Bothriolepis
text.text: A placoderm from the Late Devonian of North America. Its fossils were found in the Escuminac Formation in Quebec, Canada. It was a placoderm, 1 ft (0.3 m) long, with bony armor.

text.headline: Proganochelys
text.text: A primitive turtle from the Late Triassic of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Knollenmergel of Germany.It was a primitive turtle, 3 ft (1 m) long, with teeth on the roof of its mouth.

text.headline: Archelon
text.text: The largest turtle from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Niobrara Formation in Kansas, USA. It was the largest turtle, 13 ft (4 m) long.

text.headline: Protostega
text.text: A large turtle from the Late Cretaceous of North America. It was found in the Niobrara Formation in Kansas, USA. It was a large turtle, 10 ft (3 m) long.

text.headline: Eudimorphodon
text.text: A primitive flying reptile from the Late Triassic of Europe. Its fossils were discovered in the Zorzino Limestone in Italy. It was a primitive flying reptile, 3 ft (1 m) wingspan.

text.headline: Dimorphodon
text.text: A pterosaur from the Early Jurassic of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Lower Lias Formation of Dorset, England. It was a pterosaur, 4 ft (1.2 m) wingspan, with a large head.

text.headline: Pterodactylus
text.text: A small pterosaur from the Late Jurassic of Europe. It was discovered in the Solnhofen Limestone in Germany. It was a small pterosaur, 3 ft (1 m) wingspan, with a short tail.

text.headline: Rhamphorhynchus
text.text: A long-tailed pterosaur from the Late Jurassic of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Solnhofen Limestone in Germany. It was a long-tailed pterosaur, 3 ft (1 m) wingspan, with a diamond-shaped vane on its tail.

text.headline: Pteranodon
text.text: A large pterosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Niobrara Formation in Kansas. It was a large pterosaur, 20 ft (6 m) wingspan, with a large head crest.

text.headline: Quetzalcoatlus
text.text: The largest flying reptile from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Javelina Formation in Texas. It was the largest flying reptile, 36 ft (11 m) wingspan.

text.headline: Protosuchus
text.text: A primitive crocodile from the Early Jurassic of North America. Its fossils were found in the Kayenta Formation in Arizona. It was a primitive crocodile, 3 ft (1 m) long.

text.headline: Sarcosuchus
text.text: A giant crocodile from the Early Cretaceous of Africa. Its fossils were discovered in the Ténéré Desert in Niger. It was a giant crocodile, 40 ft (12 m) long, with an enlarged bulb on its snout.

text.headline: Deinosuchus
text.text: A giant crocodile from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Kirtland Formation of New Mexico. It was a giant crocodile, 33 ft (10 m) long, that preyed on dinosaurs.

text.headline: Petrolacosaurus
text.text: A primitive diapsid from the Late Carboniferous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Stanton Formation in Kansas. It was a primitive diapsid, 1 ft (0.3 m) long, that was the earliest-known member of the group.

text.headline: Araeoscelis
text.text: A primitive diapsid from the Early Permian of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Clear Fork Group in Texas. It was a primitive diapsid, 2 ft (0.6 m) long.

text.headline: Mesosaurus
text.text: An early marine reptile from the Early Permian of Africa and South America. It was found in the Whitehill Formation in South Africa. It was an early marine reptile, 3 ft (1 m) long.

text.headline: Lystrosaurus
text.text: A dicynodont from the Late Permian and Early Triassic of Africa and Antarctica. Its fossils were discovered in the Cynognathus Zone in South Africa. It was a dicynodont, 3 ft (1 m) long, with two tusks.

text.headline: Arctops
text.text: A gorgonopsian from the Late Permian of Africa. Its fossils were found in the Karoo Basin of South Africa. It was a gorgonopsian, 6 ft (1.8 m) long, with canine teeth.

text.headline: Ichthyosaurus
text.text: A fish-like marine reptile from the Early Jurassic of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Lias Formation of England. It was a fish-like marine reptile, 33 ft (10 m) long.

text.headline: Shonisaurus
text.text: A large ichthyosaur from the Late Triassic of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Shonisaurus State Park in Nevada. It was a large ichthyosaur, 50 ft (15 m) long.

text.headline: Liopleurodon
text.text: A large plesiosaur from the Late Jurassic of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Kimmernamege Clay of England. It was a large plesiosaur, 33 ft (10 m) long, with a short neck.

text.headline: Elasmosaurus
text.text: A long-necked plesiosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Niobrara Formation in Kansas. It was a long-necked plesiosaur, 46 ft (14 m) long, with a very long neck.

text.headline: Mosasaurus
text.text: A mosasaur from the Late Cretaceous of Europe. Its fossils were discovered in the Meuse River in the Netherlands. It was a mosasaur, 33 ft (10 m) long, with a snake-like body.

text.headline: Pliosaurus
text.text: A short-necked reptile from the Late Jurassic of Europe. It was found in the Kimmernamege Clay of Dorset, England. It was a short-necked reptile, 40 ft (12 m) long, with a massive head.

text.headline: Coelophysis
text.text: A small theropod from the Late Triassic of North America. It was found in the Ghost Ranch quarry in New Mexico, USA. It was a small theropod, 10 ft (3 m) long, that was known from many skeletons.

text.headline: Compsognathus
text.text: A small theropod from the Late Jurassic of Europe. Its fossils were discovered in the Solnhofen Limestone in Germany. It was a small theropod, 3 ft (1 m) long, that was known from two skeletons.

text.headline: Deinonychus
text.text: A dromaeosaur from the Early Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Cloverly Formation of Montana and Wyoming. It was a dromaeosaur, 10 ft (3 m) long, with a large, sickle-like claw on its foot.

text.headline: Velociraptor
text.text: A dromaeosaur from the Late Cretaceous of Asia. It was discovered in the Djadochta Formation in Mongolia. It was a dromaeosaur, 6 ft (1.8 m) long, with a large claw.

text.headline: Oviraptor
text.text: A small theropod from the Late Cretaceous of Asia. Its fossils were found in the Djadochta Formation in Mongolia. It was a small theropod, 6 ft (1.8 m) long, with a toothless skull.

text.headline: Dilophosaurus
text.text: A theropod from the Early Jurassic of North America. It was discovered in the Kayenta Formation in Arizona. It was a theropod, 20 ft (6 m) long, with two crests on its head.

text.headline: Diplodocus
text.text: A well-known sauropod from the Late Jurassic of North America. Its fossils were found in the Morrison Formation in Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming. A major site is Como Bluff, Wyoming. It was a well-known sauropod, 85 ft (26 m) long.

text.headline: Apatosaurus
text.text: A sauropod from the Late Jurassic of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Morrison Formation of Wyoming. It was a sauropod, 75 ft (23 m) long, with a heavy build.

text.headline: Brachiosaurus
text.text: A sauropod from the Late Jurassic of North America. It was found in the Morrison Formation of Colorado. It was a sauropod, 75 ft (23 m) long, with front legs longer than its back legs.

text.headline: Supersaurus
text.text: A gigantic sauropod from the Late Jurassic of North America. Its fossils were found in the Morrison Formation in Colorado. It was a gigantic sauropod, 100 ft (30 m) long.

text.headline: Argentinosaurus
text.text: A gigantic sauropod from the Late Cretaceous of South America. Its fossils were discovered in the Neuquén Basin in Argentina. It was a gigantic sauropod, 115 ft (35 m) long, with vertebrae over 5 ft tall.

text.headline: Amphicoelias
text.text: A gigantic sauropod from the Late Jurassic of North America. Its fossils were found in the Morrison Formation in Colorado. It was a gigantic sauropod, 190 ft (58 m) long, known from a single vertebra.

text.headline: Allosaurus
text.text: A large theropod from the Late Jurassic of North America. Its fossils were found in the Morrison Formation in Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming. A major site is Como Bluff, Wyoming. It was a large theropod, 36 ft (11 m) long.

text.headline: Tyrannosaurus
text.text: The largest land carnivore from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Hell Creek Formation of Montana. It was the largest land carnivore, 40 ft (12 m) long, with a massive head.

text.headline: Tarbosaurus
text.text: A tyrannosaur from the Late Cretaceous of Asia. Its fossils were found in the Nemegt Formation in Mongolia. It was a tyrannosaur, 33 ft (10 m) long, with a narrow snout.

text.headline: Spinosaurus
text.text: A large theropod from the Early Cretaceous of Africa. Its fossils were discovered in the Bahariya Formation in Egypt. It was a large theropod, 49 ft (15 m) long, with a large sail on its back.

text.headline: Giganotosaurus
text.text: A large theropod from the Early Cretaceous of South America. Its fossils were found in the Candeleros Formation in Argentina. It was a large theropod, 46 ft (14 m) long, with a large skull.

text.headline: Carcharodontosaurus
text.text: A large theropod from the Early Cretaceous of Africa. It was discovered in the Bahariya Formation in Egypt. It was a large theropod, 43 ft (13 m) long, with saw-like teeth.

text.headline: Yinlong Downsi
text.text: The first named ceratopsian from the Late Cretaceous of Asia. Its fossils were found in the Djadochta Formation in Mongolia. It was the first nameentified ceratopsian, 6 ft (1.8 m) long, with a large bony frill.

text.headline: Chasmosaurus
text.text: A ceratopsian with a very long frill from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a ceratopsian with a very long frill, 16 ft (5 m) long.

text.headline: Styracosaurus
text.text: A ceratopsian with many spikes from the Late Cretaceous of North America. It was found in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a ceratopsian with many spikes, 18 ft (5.5 m) long, featuring a large horn on its nose.

text.headline: Triceratops
text.text: The last ceratopsian from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Hell Creek Formation of Montana. It was the last ceratopsian, 30 ft (9 m) long, with three horns.

text.headline: Torosaurus
text.text: A ceratopsian with a giant frill from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Hell Creek Formation of Montana. It was a ceratopsian with a giant frill, 25 ft (7.6 m) long.

text.headline: Pachyrhinosaurus
text.text: A ceratopsian with a thick nose from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Horseshoe Canyon Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a ceratopsian with a thick nose, 20 ft (6 m) long.

text.headline: Centrosaurus
text.text: A ceratopsian with a large horn from the Late Cretaceous of North America. It was found in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a ceratopsian with a large horn, 18 ft (5.5 m) long.

text.headline: Heterodontosaurus
text.text: A primitive ornithischian from the Early Jurassic of Africa. Its fossils were found in the Elliot Formation in South Africa. It was a primitive ornithischian, 4 ft (1.2 m) long, with different kinds of teeth.

text.headline: Stegoceras
text.text: A pachycephalosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta. It was a pachycephalosaur, 8 ft (2.5 m) long, with a solname, dome-like skull.

text.headline: Pachycephalosaurus
text.text: The largest pachycephalosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Hell Creek Formation of Montana. It was the largest pachycephalosaur, 15 ft (4.5 m) long, with a very thick, bony skull cap.

text.headline: Thescelosaurus
text.text: A late surviving hypsilophodont from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Hell Creek Formation of Montana. It was a late surviving hypsilophodont, 13 ft (4 m) long, with well-preserved skeletons.

text.headline: Euparkeria
text.text: A small thecodont from the Early Triassic of Africa. Its fossils were found in the Cynognathus Zone in South Africa. It was a small thecodont, 3 ft (1 m) long, with long legs.

text.headline: Ornithosuchus
text.text: A pseudosuchian from the Late Triassic of Europe. It was discovered in the Lossiemouth Sandstone in Scotland. It was a pseudosuchian, 13 ft (4 m) long, that looked similar to a dinosaur.

text.headline: Postosuchus
text.text: A large pseudosuchian from the Late Triassic of North America. Its fossils were found in the Chinle Formation in Texas. It was a large pseudosuchian, 16 ft (5 m) long, with a large, heavy skull.

text.headline: Plateosaurus
text.text: A prosauropod from the Late Triassic of Europe. Its fossils were discovered in the Knollenmergel of Germany. It was a prosauropod, 20 ft (6 m) long, that was the most common dinosaur of its time.

text.headline: Hylonomus
text.text: A primitive lizard from the Early Carboniferous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in a petrified tree stump in the Joggins Formation, Nova Scotia. It was the first primitive lizard, 1 ft (0.3 m) long.

text.headline: Dimetrodon
text.text: A pelycosaur from the Early Permian of North America. Its fossils were found in the Clear Fork Group in Texas. It was a pelycosaur, 12 ft (3.5 m) long, with a large sail on its back.

text.headline: Edaphosaurus
text.text: A pelycosaur from the Early Permian of North America. Its fossils were found in the Clear Fork Group in Texas. It was a pelycosaur, 11 ft (3 m) long, with a tall sail on its back.

text.headline: Cotylorhynchus
text.text: A reptile from the Early Permian of North America. It was discovered in the Clear Fork Group of Oklahoma. It was a reptile, 15 ft (4.5 m) long.

text.headline: Pareiasaurus
text.text: A reptile from the Late Permian of Africa and Europe. It was found in the Ocher-Ocher Formation of Russia. It was a reptile, 8 ft (2.5 m) long, that was covered in small plates.

text.headline: Lesothosaurus
text.text: A small bipedal herbivore from the Early Jurassic of Africa. Its fossils were discovered in the Elliot Formation in Lesotho. It was a small bipedal herbivore, 3 ft (1 m) long.

text.headline: Hypsilophodon
text.text: A small bipedal herbivore from the Early Cretaceous of Europe. Fossils were discovered on the Isle of Wight, England. It was a small bipedal herbivore, 7 ft (2 m) long.

text.headline: Dryosaurus
text.text: A small bipedal herbivore from the Late Jurassic of North America. It was found in the Morrison Formation of Wyoming. It was a small bipedal herbivore, 10 ft (3 m) long.

text.headline: Camptosaurus
text.text: A primitive ornithopod from the Late Jurassic of North America. Its fossils were found in the Morrison Formation of Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming. It was a primitive ornithopod, 23 ft (7 m) long.

text.headline: Tenontosaurus
text.text: An ornithopod from the Early Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Cloverly Formation of Montana and Wyoming. It was an ornithopod, 23 ft (7 m) long, with a long tail.

text.headline: Iguanodon
text.text: A well-known ornithopod from the Early Cretaceous of Europe. It was discovered in the Wealden Group of Sussex, England. It was a well-known ornithopod, 33 ft (10 m) long, with a thumb spike.

text.headline: Hadrosaurus
text.text: The first nameentified hadrosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. It was discovered in the Navesink Formation of New Jersey, USA. It was the first nameentified hadrosaur, 30 ft (9 m) long.

text.headline: Bactrosaurus
text.text: A primitive hadrosaur from the Late Cretaceous of Asia. Its fossils were found in the Nemegt Formation of Mongolia and the Iren Dabasu Formation of China. It was a primitive hadrosaur, 20 ft (6 m) long, with a crest on its back.

text.headline: Anatosaurus
text.text: Known as the "duck lizard," this species was from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were preserved in the Lance Formation of Wyoming and the Hell Creek Formation of Montana. It was known as the "duck lizard," 33 ft (10 m) long, with well-preserved skeletons.

text.headline: Maiasaura
text.text: The "good mother lizard" from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its nesting colonies were found in the Two Medicine Formation of Montana. It was 30 ft (9 m) long, famous for its nesting colonies, indicating parental care.

text.headline: Shantungosaurus
text.text: The largest duckbilled dinosaur from the Late Cretaceous of China. Its fossils were found in the Wangshi Formation of Shandong Province. It was the largest duckbilled dinosaur, 43 ft (13 m) long.

text.headline: Kritosaurus
text.text: A hadrosaur with a nasal arch from the Late Cretaceous of North America. It was found in the Kirtland Formation of New Mexico, USA. It was a hadrosaur with a nasal arch, 33 ft (10 m) long.

text.headline: Edmontosaurus
text.text: A common flat-headed hadrosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Fossils were found in the Horseshoe Canyon Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a common flat-headed hadrosaur, 33 ft (10 m) long.

text.headline: Prosaurolophus
text.text: A crested hadrosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a hadrosaur with a small, bony lump on its head, 26 ft (8 m) long.

text.headline: Saurolophus
text.text: A hadrosaur with a solname crest from the Late Cretaceous of North America and Asia. It was found in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada, and the Nemegt Formation of Mongolia. The Canadian site is at approximately 50.730° N, 111.450° W. It was a hadrosaur with a solname, rod-like crest on its head, 30 ft (9 m) long.

text.headline: Tsintaosaurus
text.text: A hadrosaur with an upright crest from the Late Cretaceous of Asia. Its fossils were found in the Wangshi Formation of Shandong Province, China. It was a hadrosaur with an upright, single horn-like crest, 33 ft (10 m) long.

text.headline: Corythosaurus
text.text: A hadrosaur with a helmet-like crest from the Late Cretaceous of North America. It was discovered in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a hadrosaur with a tall, helmet-like crest, 30 ft (9 m) long, possibly used for sound production.

text.headline: Lambeosaurus
text.text: A hadrosaur with a hollow crest from the Late Cretaceous of North America. It was found in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a hadrosaur with a distinct, hollow crest, 30 ft (9 m) long.

text.headline: Hypacrosaurus
text.text: A hadrosaur with a broad, flat crest from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Fossils were found in the Horseshoe Canyon Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a hadrosaur with a broad, flat crest, 30 ft (9 m) long.

text.headline: Parasaurolophus
text.text: A hadrosaur with a long, tubular crest from the Late Cretaceous of North America. It was found in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a hadrosaur with a long, tubular crest, 30 ft (9 m) long, likely used for vocalization.

text.headline: Stegosaurus
text.text: A well-known stegosaur from the Late Jurassic of North America. It was found in the Morrison Formation of Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming. A major site is Como Bluff, Wyoming. It was a well-known stegosaur, 30 ft (9 m) long, with two rows of triangular plates on its back and tail spikes.

text.headline: Kentrosaurus
text.text: A smaller stegosaur from the Late Jurassic of Africa. Its fossils were discovered in the Tendaguru Formation in Tanzania. It was a smaller stegosaur, 16 ft (5 m) long, featuring broad plates on its front and long, sharp spikes on its back and tail.

text.headline: Tuojiangosaurus
text.text: A stegosaur from the Late Jurassic of China. Its fossils were found in the Upper Shaximiao Formation in Sichuan Province. It was a stegosaur, 23 ft (7 m) long, with tall dorsal spines and two tail spikes.

text.headline: Wuerhosaurus
text.text: A stegosaur from the Early Cretaceous of China. Fossils were discovered in the Tugulu Group in the Junggar Basin, Xinjiang. It was a stegosaur, 20 ft (6 m) long, with low, flat plates.

text.headline: Hylaeosaurus
text.text: An ankylosaur from the Early Cretaceous of Europe. It was discovered in the Wealden Group of Sussex, England. It was an ankylosaur, 20 ft (6 m) long, covered in bony plates and spikes.

text.headline: Polacanthus
text.text: An ankylosaur from the Early Cretaceous of Europe. Fossils were found on the Isle of Wight, England. It was an ankylosaur, 13 ft (4 m) long, featuring a shield of fused bony plates over its hips.

text.headline: Sauropelta
text.text: A nodosaur from the Early Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Cloverly Formation of Montana and Wyoming. It was a nodosaur, 25 ft (7.6 m) long, with large, flat plates over its neck and shoulders.

text.headline: Silvisaurus
text.text: A small nodosaur from the Early Cretaceous of North America. Fossils were found in the Dakota Formation of Kansas, USA. It was a small nodosaur, 13 ft (4 m) long, with a domed skull and conical spikes.

text.headline: Struthiosaurus
text.text: A small nodosaur from the Late Cretaceous of Europe. It was discovered in the Gosau Group of Austria. It was a small nodosaur, 10 ft (3 m) long.

text.headline: Nodosaurus
text.text: The typical nodosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. It was found in the Frontier Formation of Wyoming. It was the typical nodosaur, 18 ft (5.5 m) long, known from one skeleton.

text.headline: Euoplocephalus
text.text: A well-known ankylosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a well-known ankylosaur, 18 ft (5.5 m) long, with a broad, flat skull and a bony club tail.

text.headline: Talarurus
text.text: An ankylosaur from the Late Cretaceous of Asia. Its fossils were discovered in the Nemegt Formation in Mongolia. It was an ankylosaur, 16 ft (5 m) long, with a narrow skull and a large tail club.

text.headline: Saichania
text.text: An ankylosaur from the Late Cretaceous of Asia. Fossils were found in the Nemegt Formation in Mongolia. It was an ankylosaur, 16 ft (5 m) long, with a heavily armored skull and large nasal passages.

text.headline: Panoplosaurus
text.text: A nodosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Its fossils were found in the Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta, Canada. It was a nodosaur, 20 ft (6 m) long, with prominent spikes and shoulder plates.

text.headline: Ankylosaurus
text.text: The largest and last ankylosaur from the Late Cretaceous of North America. Fossils were found in the Hell Creek Formation of Montana, USA. It was the largest and last ankylosaur, 30 ft (9 m) long, with a massive tail club and extensive armor.

text.headline: Ichthyostega
text.text: The first amphibian from the Late Devonian of Europe. It was discovered in eastern Greenland. Widely thought of as the first amphibian, or four-legged fish. 5 ft (1.5 m) long.

text.headline: Eryops
text.text: An amphibian from the Early Permian of North America. Its fossils were discovered in the Clear Fork Group in Texas. It was an amphibian, 6 ft (1.8 m) long, with a broad skull.

text.headline: Diplocaulus
text.text: An amphibian from the Early Permian of North America. Its fossils were found in the Clear Fork Group in Texas. It was an amphibian, 3 ft (1 m) long, with a boomerang-shaped head.

text.headline: Seymouria
text.text: An amphibian from the Early Permian of North America. It was discovered in the Clear Fork Group of Texas. It was an amphibian, 2 ft (0.6 m) long, that was well-adapted for life on land.

text.headline: Acanthostega
text.text: A fish-amphibian from the Late Devonian of Europe. Its fossils were found in the Canis Formation in Greenland. It was a fish-amphibian, 2 ft (0.6 m) long, that had both gills and lungs.
